text: Damn, what's with all this hate everywhere? If someone wants to buy an iPhone, let them buy it, so what? Likewise, if someone wants to buy an Android phone, let them buy it as well, so what? People have different tastes and reasons. If iPhone sales increase and more people want to buy it, then kudos to iPhone's marketing team for doing a good job for their company. Same goes with companies like Samsung and Google. Calling others "sheeps" or saying that the quality of iPhones are better isn't doing you any good. It's just making you look more foolish because all you care about is one-upping yourself when in reality, the decisions of other people literally shouldn't have an impact on you. If that isn't the case, well there's clearly something wrong with you. If you really want something to bash on, go towards all the hypebeast products, but at the end of the day, it's the same thing all over again.Ôªø

text: "Dual sim which most phones don't have." I don't know about that, most iPhone's don't have it. "You can get up to 512GB of storage, which is a lot." Yeah but you have to pay extra for the extra storage, several hundreds of dollars more (from the $999 starting price) and on most flagship android's you can just get an SD card for less than half of that. "It's so fast." Yeah every flagship phone today is so fast that you can barely tell the difference, especially since you showed us that it can't just instantly (or even almost instantly) boot up a graphics intensive game so you had to cut the loading out. That shows that it isn't too much faster than a Note 9 for example. I was really excited when I found out that the new iPhones were announced but I guess there really isn't anything noteworthy in the "new" lineup. That $750 "cheaper version" of the iPhone X is garbage for its price, they try to justify the loss of dpi and such by comparing it to the ridiculous price of the X instead of comparing the XR to other android flagships that are in the same price range. And also you can change the background focus of any image taken on any phone after taking the picture, it might not look as good except if you know what you're doing and took a proper format picture beforehand. There really isn't anything about these phones that make them stand out. I guess we'll have to wait for the X2.Ôªø

author: Howard Ng

text:
To everyone that keeps saying its so expensive read:

An iPhone is $41.63 (per month) for installment plan through AT&T For me. Base model Xs. I can upgrade every 12 or 24 months no contract! Thats $499.56 if I upgrade every year, every time a new iPhone comes out. All I do is pay the taxes on the new phone upfront and send AT&T back the old one within a time frame. I have never had issues. You can also choose to pay off the remaining installments and keep the phone. Or sell it (like me) for more than the remaining installments and make a profit. Because they send you the new phone while you still have the old one. Not really expensive at all. $499.56 is awesome for a brand new iPhone every single year. I don‚Äôt understand why everyone keeps saying its so expensive when a Samsung flagship is ~50-100$ less ?Ôªø

author: Frank Spalding

text:
Remy De la Cruz I haven‚Äôt signed not one contract also you still have not told me how 499 a year for a new phone is less than 1,000 a year with no upgrade option the next year. You keep bringing up how its a lease and stuff of course it is. And you can ‚Äútake it back‚Äù its called surrendering if you fall in hard times just send it back not that hard. I know what I sign up for obviously im not going to ‚Äúquit‚Äù my carrier with a leased phone like you keep saying. Same as if it was a car not gonna quit the bank and go somewhere else lol you cant. The upgrade plan is not for everyone. If you want to shell out full price every single year for a flagship phone you can if thats what you like its up to you. Personally i would rather get a new phone for half the cost every year and give back my old one. Its not hard theres no strings attached theres no damn apr% theres not one piece of paper i had to sign. If your smart like me you sell the old phone for over the remaining ‚Äúlease balance‚Äù and make a profit so essentially im not paying any more real money towards the new phone every year and i make an extra 100 or so dollars from the sale. Seriously it doesn‚Äôt take a scientist to figure basic math. It benefits me and so many others, the upgrade plan if it didn‚Äôt then iPhone wouldn‚Äôt have created there own program to do so as well. 

A chart of a breakdown of an iPhone over 2 years:

Option 1: Buy phone upfront cost.

Year 1 - 1,000 + tax
Year 2 - 1,000 + tax (because oh I wanted the new phone) 

Total - Over 2,000 

Option 2:

Year 1 - pay taxes only to get phone initially = around 80$ something dollars

Then pay $41.76 a month for 12 months then upgrade IF you like total around 580 something for one year.

Year 2 - taxes down on another phone and same monthly prices and upgrade option. 

Toal 1,160 approximately.

Now good sir how is that more than option 1 ? Oh and i didn‚Äôt mention the option to sell the phone and make a profit so it could be a lot cheaper. Im not even going to go into you buying a phone right out and attaching apple care which would be around 1300 dollars every year. Or do the iPhone Upgrade option that includes and unlock phone with apple care for 49 a month you do the math.Ôªø

author: Sri Thao

text:
Unintelligent comment. Objectively:

- New, faster A12 chip with a vastly improved Neural Engine.
- 120hz touching sensing
- Better water resistance
- Improved battery life
- Faster, new GPU
- Bigger sensor and improved ISP on the camera

What's robbery is when the likes of Samsung use bargain basement components with high clocks in a mish-mash architectural configuration, and sell their phones at a similar price to iPhone. They're deceiving those who think "oh, big numbers must mean better", which hasn't been the case for yonks. At least with iPhone, everything is designed in-house for cohesive architectural set up.Ôªø

1.4u is just a spec spec, nothing more.
Adjustable bokeh is obviously much improved here, where it is an unusable gimmick on the Samsung hastly implemented to attract idiots who only read spec sheets.

Zmantech !

text: The reason why they do this is because 1. iPhone is more of a fashion brand company trying to get its name out. Therefore they keep the same design with its minimal clear logo on the back so people recognize the brand easily. This cannot be said easily with phones like the LG G series, Samsung S series, Oneplus, etc all looking the same at the screen side with slight variations on the cameras. 2. The average person doesn't like change. If iPhone goes bold, they may lose customers (and potential money). We all know how money hungry they are. They keep it all the same so people have security that they won't have to learn a bunch of new features. They keep everything the same so it's easily recognizable to anyone. It's indirect advertisement.Ôªø

text: @Matthew Gonzales Also you're right, but their features are nothing to go home about. They did add features, like 3D touch, animoji,  touch id, an excellent taptic vibrator, FaceID, dual cameras, but it's nothing to rave about, except faceid, but that's gated behind the X. author: dozer games

text:
Then you should use an Android. Because iPhone is supposed to make the average (majority) user free from customization, the user should be able to pick it up and use it right away and no need to think about it.

I can see Android is more suitable for you, but trust me, you have no idea how chaotic Android user experience is for users who are not like you and me (who are into tech), they even struggle to understand desktop and app drawer and they're not supposed to! It's like thinking of the pen while writing all the time (which the user should only think about the content they want to deliver instead).

For the price, my opinion is, real innovation comes from iPhone, and I don't mean new ideas, I mean good hardware and software experience that user can adopt, those comes from their R&D. Just imagine a world without iPhone, who else can they copy from? And because their iOS is so good, we don't even need to buy the flagship, just get an iPhone 7 (USD449 - 32gb) or even an iPhone 5s (USD290 - 64gb) model. In a long run, you spend less on iPhone than Android. https://www.statista.com/chart/5824/ios-iphone-compatibility/

Again, if you're a power user who needs customization, Android is the best choice. Cheers.Ôªø

text: @Tim Powell nope. Hdr refers to the number of bits used for color depth. The brightest and dimmest settings will be the same as a non-hdr screen, but the number of colors in-between are greater.Ôªø
author: Hayes Clark

text: I don't know much about screens but I do some photography and as far as I was aware the process to make an HDR imagine is to take multiple images at different exposures to combine them to keep definition in very dark areas and very light areas. I don't see what this has to do with colour. The Dynamic in HDR surely is to do with brightness. Could be wrong thoughÔªø

author: Juma Aljbar

text: @Tim Powell An HDR combined image in photography isn't quite the same. Combining three different pictures gets the best parts of each picture (like detailed shadows, nice contrast in the sky etc), but all properly exposed. HDR on a TV refers to the fact that the TV has capability to see a high dynamic range (in the color aspect). There is a brightness dynamic range and a color dynamic rangeÔªø

Its $41.63 (per month) for installment plan through AT&T For me. Base model Xs. I can upgrade every 12 or 24 months no contract! text: Eli Czaplinski I can't believe people are ignorant to this point. Smh. As the years go by applications get bugger in size. Especially games for example. They become higher quality have more features etc and consequently take require more space. And its not just apps. Even photos and videos are getting higher quality e.g 4k which consumers more gegabite. So as a  result the same phone storage sizes we once thought were big are now getting relatively smaller and smaller. Not literally. But indirectly compared to the rowing size of apps. So as a result we need bigger memory sizes to make up for this increase in app sizes etc. of course not everyone's use will necessarily need such levels of gb but even then its nice to know you will never have to transfer or delete files ever again basically. You can just take as many photos as you want and download as many apps as you want without ever worrying about storage. And its especially important for power heavy uses who use big giant business or other apps on their phone.  So these 128 gb and 512 gb  models have their market definetly.Ôªø
